discussion.content:
Application layer test commands don’t display information in real time, but they do show statistics and
configuration information about a feature or process. You can also use some of these commands to restart a
process or execute a change in its operation.

Selected Answer: BC
Some of them can be used to restart an application.

choices.D: Some of them only display output, after you run the diagnose debug console enable command.
choices.C: Some of them display statistics and configuration information about a feature or process.
choices.A: Some of them display real-time application debugs.
choices.B: Some of them can be used to restart an application.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit, which contains a CLI script configuration on FortiManager.
//IMG//

An administrator configured the CLI script on FortiManager, but the script failed to apply any changes to the managed device after being executed.
What are two reasons why the script did not make any changes to the managed device? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BD
BD
Enterprise_Firewall_7.0_Study_Guide-Online.pdf page 260

Selected Answer: BD
B and D

Selected Answer: BD
This is CLI script so B and D.

Selected Answer: BD
"#!" Needed to start TCL Scripts
CLI scripts will ignore commands starting with "#"
CLI scripts will fail if commands are not complete ("config router static" vs "conf rout stat")

Selected Answer: BD
ref CLI scripts do not include Tool Command Language (Tcl) commands, and the first line of the script is not “#!” as it is for Tcl scripts.
https://help.fortinet.com/fmgr/50hlp/56/5-6-1/FortiManager_Admin_Guide/1000_Device%20Manager/2400_Scripts/1000_Script%20samples/0200_CLI%20scripts+.htm

Selected Answer: BD
When Creating CLI scripts, follow these best practices:
1) Use complete FortiOS CLI commands.
2) Comment lines that start with the number sign (#) do not run.
3) Ensure you set the console output to standard.

Selected Answer: BD
It is CLI script, not TCL. Only TCL script must begin with #!
From Study Guide:
The best practice when creating CLI script> use complete FortiOS CLI commands.

Selected Answer: BC
this B C
trap C has #!. it is necessary that either #!
trap B has #!. it is necessary that either #!

comments.content: first line must be #! in the case of TCL script and this is not a TCL script in the image, C is wrong

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
first line must be #! and all other # is for comments and are not processed

choices.B: The commands that start with the # sign did not run.
choices.D: Incomplete commands can cause CLI scripts to fail.
choices.A: Static routes can be added using only TCL scripts.
